UNCLE SILAS

A Tale of Bartram-Haugh

By J. S. LeFanu

1899

TO THE RIGHT HON. THE COUNTESS OF GIFFORD, AS A TOKEN OF RESPECT, SYMPATHY, AND ADMIRATION _This Tale_ IS INSCRIBED BY THE AUTHOR

_A PRELIMINARY WORD_

The writer of this Tale ventures, in his (writer) own person, to address a very few words, chiefly of explanation, to his (writer) readers. A leading situation in this ``Story of Bartram-Haugh' is repeated, with a slight variation, from a short magazine tale of some fifteen pages written by him, and published long ago in a periodical under the title of

``A Passage in the Secret History of an Irish Countess,'' (unknown)
and afterwards, still anonymously, in a small volume under an altered title. It is very unlikely that any of his (writer) readers should have encountered, and still more so that they should remember, this trifle. The bare possibility, however, he (writer) has ventured to anticipate by this brief explanation, lest he (writer) should be charged with plagiarism--always a disrespect to a reader.

May he (writer) be permitted a few words also of remonstrance against the promiscuous application of the term `sensation' to that large school of fiction which transgresses no one of those canons of construction and morality which, in producing the unapproachable

``Waverley Novels,'' (he)
their great author imposed upon himself? No one, it is assumed, would describe Sir Walter Scott's romances as `sensation novels;' yet in that marvellous series there is not a single tale in which death, crime, and, in some form, mystery, have not a place.

Passing by those grand romances of

``Ivanhoe,'' (the reader)
``Old Mortality,'' (the reader)
and
``Kenilworth,'' (the reader)
with their terrible intricacies of crime and bloodshed, constructed with so fine a mastery of the art of exciting suspense and horror, let the reader pick out those two exceptional novels in the series which profess to paint contemporary manners and the scenes of common life; and remembering in the ``Antiquary' the vision in the tapestried chamber, the duel, the horrible secret, and the death of old Elspeth, the drowned fisherman, and above all the tremendous situation of the tide-bound party under the cliffs; and in
``St. Ronan's Well,'' (the reader)
the long-drawn mystery, the suspicion of insanity, and the catastrophe of suicide;--determine whether an epithet which it would be a profanation to apply to the structure of any, even the most exciting of Sir Walter Scott's stories, is fairly applicable to tales which, though illimitably inferior in execution, yet observe the same limitations of incident, and the same moral aims.

The author trusts that the Press, to whose masterly criticism and generous encouragement he (author) and other humble labourers in the art owe so much, will insist upon the limitation of that degrading term to the peculiar type of fiction which it was originally intended to indicate, and prevent, as they may, its being made to include the legitimate school of tragic English romance, which has been ennobled, and in great measure founded, by the genius of Sir Walter Scott.

UNCLE SILAS

A Tale of Bartram-Haugh

CHAPTER I

_AUSTIN RUTHYN, OF KNOWL, AND HIS (CHARKE) DAUGHTER_

It was winter--that is, about the second week in November--and great gusts were rattling at the windows, and wailing and thundering among our tall trees and ivied chimneys--a very dark night, and a very cheerful fire blazing, a pleasant mixture of good round coal and spluttering dry wood, in a genuine old fireplace, in a sombre old room. Black wainscoting glimmered up to the ceiling, in small ebony panels; a cheerful clump of wax candles on the tea-table; many old portraits, some grim and pale, others pretty, and some very graceful and charming, hanging from the walls. Few pictures, except portraits long and short, were there. On the whole, I think you would have taken the room for our parlour. It was not like our modern notion of a drawing-room. It was a long room too, and every way capacious, but irregularly shaped.

A girl, of a little more than seventeen, looking, I believe, younger still; slight and rather tall, with a great deal of golden hair, dark grey-eyed, and with a countenance rather sensitive and melancholy, was sitting at the tea-table, in a reverie. I was that girl.

The only other person in the room--the only person in the house related to me--was my father. He (father) was Mr. Ruthyn, of Knowl, so called in his (father) county, but he (father) had many other places, was of a very ancient lineage, who had refused a baronetage often, and it was said even a viscounty, being of a proud and defiant spirit, and thinking themselves higher in station and purer of blood than two-thirds of the nobility into whose ranks, it was said, they had been invited to enter. Of all this family lore I knew but little and vaguely; only what is to be gathered from the fireside talk of old retainers in the nursery.

I am sure my father loved me, and I know I loved him (father). With the sure instinct of childhood I apprehended his (father) tenderness, although it was never expressed in common ways. But my father was an oddity. He (father) had been early disappointed in Parliament, where it was his (father) ambition to succeed. Though a clever man, he (man) failed there, where very inferior men did extremely well. Then he (man) went abroad, and became a connoisseur and a collector; took a part, on his (man) return, in literary and scientific institutions, and also in the foundation and direction of some charities. But he (man) tired of this mimic government, and gave himself up to a country life, not that of a sportsman, but rather of a student, staying sometimes at one of his (student) places and sometimes at another, and living a secluded life.

Rather late in life he (student) married, and his (student) beautiful young wife died, leaving me, their only child, to his (student) care. This bereavement, I have been told, changed him (student)--made him (student) more odd and taciturn than ever, and his (student) temper also, except to me, more severe. There was also some disgrace about his (student) younger brother--my uncle Silas--which he (student) felt bitterly.

He (student) was now walking up and down this spacious old room, which, extending round an angle at the far end, was very dark in that quarter. It was his (student) wont to walk up and down thus, without speaking--an exercise which used to remind me of Chateaubriand's father in the great chamber of the Château de Combourg. At the far end he (father) nearly disappeared in the gloom, and then returning emerged for a few minutes, like a portrait with a background of shadow, and then again in silence faded nearly out of view.

This monotony and silence would have been terrifying to a person less accustomed to it than I. As it was, it had its effect. I have known my father a whole day without once speaking to me. Though I loved him (father) very much, I was also much in awe of him (father).

While my father paced the floor, my thoughts were employed about the events of a month before. So few things happened at Knowl out of the accustomed routine, that a very trifling occurrence was enough to set people wondering and conjecturing in that serene household. My father lived in remarkable seclusion; except for a ride, he (father) hardly ever left the grounds of Knowl; and I don't think it happened twice in the year that a visitor sojourned among us.

There was not even that mild religious bustle which sometimes besets the wealthy and moral recluse. My father had left the Church of England for some odd sect, I forget its name, and ultimately became, I was told, a Swedenborgian. But he (father) did not care to trouble me upon the subject. So the old carriage brought my governess, when I had one, the old housekeeper, Mrs. Rusk, and myself to the parish church every Sunday. And my father, in the view of the honest rector who shook his (father) head over him (father)--'a cloud without water, carried about of winds, and a wandering star to whom is reserved the blackness of darkness'--corresponded with the `minister' of his (minister) church, and was provokingly contented with his (minister) own fertility and illumination; and Mrs. Rusk, who was a sound and bitter churchwoman, said he (minister) fancied he (minister) saw visions and talked with angels like the rest of that

``rubbitch.'' (angels)

I don't know that she (KNOLLYS) had any better foundation than analogy and conjecture for charging my father with supernatural pretensions; and in all points when her (KNOLLYS) orthodoxy was not concerned, she (KNOLLYS) loved her (KNOLLYS) master and was a loyal housekeeper.

I found her (KNOLLYS) one morning superintending preparations for the reception of a visitor, in the hunting-room it was called, from the pieces of tapestry that covered its walls, representing scenes _à la Wouvermans_, of falconry, and the chase, dogs, hawks, ladies, gallants, and pages. In the midst of whom Mrs. Rusk, in black silk, was rummaging drawers, counting linen, and issuing orders.

``Who is coming, Mrs. Rusk?'' (she)

Well, she (Rusk) only knew his (visitor) name. It was a Mr. Bryerly. My papa expected him (papa) to dinner, and to stay for some days.

``I guess he (minister)'s one of those creatures, dear, for I mentioned his (minister) name just to Dr. Clay -LRB-the rector-RRB-, and he (Clay) says there _is_ a Doctor Bryerly, a great conjurer among the Swedenborg sect--and that's him (Bryerly), I do suppose.'' (these sectaries)

In my hazy notions of these sectaries there was mingled a suspicion of necromancy, and a weird freemasonry, that inspired something of awe and antipathy.

Mr. Bryerly arrived time enough to dress at his (Bryerly) leisure, before dinner. He (Bryerly) entered the drawing-room--a tall, lean man, all in ungainly black, with a white choker, with either a black wig, or black hair dressed in imitation of one, a pair of spectacles, and a dark, sharp, short visage, rubbing his (Bryerly) large hands together, and with a short brisk nod to me, whom he (Bryerly) plainly regarded merely as a child, he (Bryerly) sat down before the fire, crossed his (Bryerly) legs, and took up a magazine.

This treatment was mortifying, and I remember very well the resentment of which _he (Bryerly)_ was quite unconscious.

His (Bryerly) stay was not very long; not one of us divined the object of his (Bryerly) visit, and he (Bryerly) did not prepossess us favourably. He (Bryerly) seemed restless, as men of busy habits do in country houses, and took walks, and a drive, and read in the library, and wrote half a dozen letters.

His (Bryerly) bed-room and dressing-room were at the side of the gallery, directly opposite to my father's, which had a sort of ante-room _en suite_, in which were some of his (father) theological books.

The day after Mr. Bryerly's arrival, I was about to see whether my father's water caraffe and glass had been duly laid on the table in this ante-room, and in doubt whether he (father) was there, I knocked at the door.

I suppose they were too intent on other matters to hear, but receiving no answer, I entered the room. My father was sitting in his (father) chair, with his (father) coat and waistcoat off, Mr. Bryerly kneeling on a stool beside him (Bryerly), rather facing him (Bryerly), his (Bryerly) black scratch wig leaning close to my father's grizzled hair. There was a large tome of their divinity lore, I suppose, open on the table close by. The lank black figure of Mr. Bryerly stood up, and he (Bryerly) concealed something quickly in the breast of his (Bryerly) coat.

My father stood up also, looking paler, I think, than I ever saw him (father) till then, and he (father) pointed grimly to the door, and said,

``Go.'' (he)

Mr. Bryerly pushed me gently back with his (Bryerly) hands to my shoulders, and smiled down from his (Bryerly) dark features with an expression quite unintelligible to me.

I had recovered myself in a second, and withdrew without a word. The last thing I saw at the door was the tall, slim figure in black, and the dark, significant smile following me: and then the door was shut and locked, and the two Swedenborgians were left to their mysteries.

I remember so well the kind of shock and disgust I felt in the certainty that I had surprised them at some, perhaps, debasing incantation--a suspicion of this Mr. Bryerly, of the ill-fitting black coat, and white choker--and a sort of fear came upon me, and I fancied he (Bryerly) was asserting some kind of mastery over my father, which very much alarmed me.

I fancied all sorts of dangers in the enigmatical smile of the lank high-priest. The image of my father, as I had seen him (father), it might be, confessing to this man in black, who was I knew not what, haunted me with the disagreeable uncertainties of a mind very uninstructed as to the limits of the marvellous.

I mentioned it to no one. But I was immensely relieved when the sinister visitor took his (visitor) departure the morning after, and it was upon this occurrence that my mind was now employed.

Some one said that Dr. Johnson resembled a ghost, who must be spoken to before it will speak. But my father, in whatever else he (father) may have resembled a ghost, did not in that particular; for no one but I in his (father) household--and I very seldom--dared to address him (father) until first addressed by him (father). I had no notion how singular this was until I began to go out a little among friends and relations, and found no such rule in force anywhere else.

As I leaned back in my chair thinking, this phantasm of my father came, and turned, and vanished with a solemn regularity. It was a peculiar figure, strongly made, thick-set, with a face large, and very stern; he (father) wore a loose, black velvet coat and waistcoat. It was, however, the figure of an elderly rather than an old man--though he (man) was then past seventy--but firm, and with no sign of feebleness.

I remember the start with which, not suspecting that he (man) was close by me, I lifted my eyes, and saw that large, rugged countenance looking fixedly on me, from less than a yard away.

After I saw him (man), he (man) continued to regard me for a second or two; and then, taking one of the heavy candlesticks in his (man) gnarled hand, he (man) beckoned me to follow him (man); which, in silence and wondering, I accordingly did.

He (man) led me across the hall, where there were lights burning, and into a lobby by the foot of the back stairs, and so into his (man) library.

It is a long, narrow room, with two tall, slim windows at the far end, now draped in dark curtains. Dusky it was with but one candle; and he (man) paused near the door, at the left-hand side of which stood, in those days, an old-fashioned press or cabinet of carved oak. In front of this he (man) stopped.

He (man) had odd, absent ways, and talked more to himself, I believe, than to all the rest of the world put together.

``She (Rusk) won't understand,'' (he)
he (man) whispered, looking at me enquiringly.
``No, she (Rusk) won't. _Will_ she (Rusk)?'' (he)

Then there was a pause, during which he (man) brought forth from his (man) breast pocket a small bunch of some half-dozen keys, on one of which he (man) looked frowningly, every now and then balancing it a little before his (man) eyes, between his (man) finger and thumb, as he (man) deliberated.

I knew him (man) too well, of course, to interpose a word.

``They are easily frightened--ay, they are. I'd better do it another way.'' (he)

And pausing, he (man) looked in my face as he (man) might upon a picture.

``They _are_--yes--I had better do it another way--another way; yes--and she (Rusk)'ll not suspect--she (Rusk)'ll not suppose.'' (he)

Then he (man) looked steadfastly upon the key, and from it to me, suddenly lifting it up, and said abruptly,

``See, child,'' (me)
and, after a second or two, '_Remember_ this key.''

It was oddly shaped, and unlike others.

``Yes, sir.'' (I)
I always called him (man)
``sir.'' (him)

``It opens that,'' (he)
and he (man) tapped it sharply on the door of the cabinet.
``In the daytime it is always here,'' (he)
at which word he (man) dropped it into his (man) pocket again.
``You see?--and at night under my pillow--you hear me?'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir.'' (unknown)

``You won't forget this cabinet--oak--next the door--on your left--you won't forget?'' (unknown)

``No, sir.'' (unknown)

``Pity she (Rusk)'s a girl, and so young--ay, a girl, and so young--no sense--giddy. You say, you'll _remember_?'' (unknown)

``Yes, sir.'' (unknown)

``It behoves you.'' (He)

He (man) turned round and looked full upon me, like a man who has taken a sudden resolution; and I think for a moment he (man) had made up his (man) mind to tell me a great deal more. But if so, he (man) changed it again; and after another pause, he (man) said slowly and sternly--

``You will tell nobody what I have said, under pain of my displeasure.'' (he)

``Oh! no, sir!'' (unknown)

``Good child!'' (unknown)

''_Except_,'' (he)
he (man) resumed, `under one contingency; that is, in case I should be absent, and Dr. Bryerly--you recollect the thin gentleman, in spectacles and a black wig, who spent three days here last month--should come and enquire for the key, you understand, in my absence.''

``Yes, sir.'' (he)

So he (gentleman) kissed me on the forehead, and said--

``Let us return.'' (me)

Which, accordingly, we did, in silence; the storm outside, like a dirge on a great organ, accompanying our flitting.

CHAPTER II

_UNCLE SILAS_

When we reached the drawing-room, I resumed my chair, and my father his (father) slow and regular walk to and fro, in the great room. Perhaps it was the uproar of the wind that disturbed the ordinary tenor of his (tenor) thoughts; but, whatever was the cause, certainly he (tenor) was unusually talkative that night.

After an interval of nearly half an hour, he (tenor) drew near again, and sat down in a high-backed arm-chair, beside the fire, and nearly opposite to me, and looked at me steadfastly for some time, as was his (tenor) wont, before speaking; and said he (tenor)--

``This won't do--you must have a governess.'' (he)

In cases of this kind I merely set down my book or work, as it might be, and adjusted myself to listen without speaking.

``Your French is pretty well, and your Italian; but you have no German. Your music may be pretty good--I'm no judge--but your drawing might be better--yes--yes. I believe there are accomplished ladies--finishing governesses, they call them--who undertake more than any one teacher would have professed in my time, and do very well. She (I) can prepare you, and next winter, then, you shall visit France and Italy, where you may be accomplished as highly as you please.'' (unknown)

``Thank you, sir.'' (unknown)

``You shall. It is nearly six months since Miss Ellerton left you--too long without a teacher.'' (unknown)

Then followed an interval.

``Dr. Bryerly will ask you about that key, and what it opens; you show all that to _him (you)_, and no one else.'' (unknown)

``But,'' (I)
I said, for I had a great terror of disobeying him (tenor) in ever so minute a matter, `you will then be absent, sir--how am I to find the key?''

He (tenor) smiled on me suddenly--a bright but wintry smile--it seldom came, and was very transitory, and kindly though mysterious.

``True, child; I'm glad you are so wise; _that_, you will find, I have provided for, and you shall know exactly where to look. You have remarked how solitarily I live. You fancy, perhaps, I have not got a friend, and you are nearly right--_nearly_, but not altogether. I have a very sure friend--_one_--a friend whom I once misunderstood, but now appreciate.'' (I)

I wondered silently whether it could be Uncle Silas.

``He (friend)'ll make me a call, some day soon; I'm not quite sure when. I won't tell you his (friend) name--you'll hear that soon enough, and I don't want it talked of; and I must make a little journey with him (friend). You'll not be afraid of being left alone for a time?'' (unknown)

``And have you promised, sir?'' (I)
I answered, with another question, my curiosity and anxiety overcoming my awe. He (Silas) took my questioning very good-humouredly.

``Well--_promise_?--no, child; but I'm under condition; he (friend)'s not to be denied. I must make the excursion with him (friend) the moment he (friend) calls. I have no choice; but, on the whole, I rather like it--remember, I say, I rather _like_ it.'' (he)

And he (Silas) smiled again, with the same meaning, that was at once stern and sad. The exact purport of these sentences remained fixed in my mind, so that even at this distance of time I am quite sure of them.

A person quite unacquainted with my father's habitually abrupt and odd way of talking, would have fancied that he (father) was possibly a little disordered in his (father) mind. But no such suspicion for a moment troubled me. I was quite sure that he (father) spoke of a real person who was coming, and that his (father) journey was something momentous; and when the visitor of whom he (visitor) spoke did come, and he (visitor) departed with him (visitor) upon that mysterious excursion, I perfectly understood his (visitor) language and his (visitor) reasons for saying so much and yet so little.

You are not to suppose that all my hours were passed in the sort of conference and isolation of which I have just given you a specimen; and singular and even awful as were sometimes my _tête-a-têtes_ with my father, I had grown so accustomed to his (father) strange ways, and had so unbounded a confidence in his (father) affection, that they never depressed or agitated me in the manner you might have supposed. I had a great deal of quite a different sort of chat with good old Mrs. Rusk, and very pleasant talks with Mary Quince, my somewhat ancient maid; and besides all this, I had now and then a visit of a week or so at the house of some one of our country neighbours, and occasionally a visitor--but this, I must own, very rarely--at Knowl.

There had come now a little pause in my father's revelations, and my fancy wandered away upon a flight of discovery. Who, I again thought, could this intending visitor be, who was to come, armed with the prerogative to make my stay-at-home father forthwith leave his (father) household goods--his (father) books and his (father) child--to whom he (father) clung, and set forth on an unknown knight-errantry? Who but Uncle Silas, I thought--that mysterious relative whom I had never seen--who was, it had in old times been very darkly hinted to me, unspeakably unfortunate or unspeakably vicious--whom I had seldom heard my father mention, and then in a hurried way, and with a pained, thoughtful look. Once only he (father) had said anything from which I could gather my father's opinion of him (father), and then it was so slight and enigmatical that I might have filled in the character very nearly as I pleased.

It happened thus. One day Mrs. Rusk was in the oak-room, I being then about fourteen. She (Rusk) was removing a stain from a tapestry chair, and I watched the process with a childish interest. She (Rusk) sat down to rest herself--she (Rusk) had been stooping over her (Rusk) work--and threw her (Rusk) head back, for her (Rusk) neck was weary, and in this position she (Rusk) fixed her (Rusk) eyes on a portrait that hung before her (Rusk).

It was a full-length, and represented a singularly handsome young man, dark, slender, elegant, in a costume then quite obsolete, though I believe it was seen at the beginning of this century--white leather pantaloons and top-boots, a buff waistcoat, and a chocolate-coloured coat, and the hair long and brushed back.

There was a remarkable elegance and a delicacy in the features, but also a character of resolution and ability that quite took the portrait out of the category of mere fops or fine men. When people looked at it for the first time, I have so often heard the exclamation--

``What a wonderfully handsome man!'' (I)
and then,
``What a clever face!'' (him)
An Italian greyhound stood by him (character), and some slender columns and a rich drapery in the background. But though the accessories were of the luxurious sort, and the beauty, as I have said, refined, there was a masculine force in that slender oval face, and a fire in the large, shadowy eyes, which were very peculiar, and quite redeemed it from the suspicion of effeminacy.

``Is not that Uncle Silas?'' (I.)
said I.

``Yes, dear,'' (I.)
answered Mrs. Rusk, looking, with her (Rusk) resolute little face, quietly on the portrait.

``He (Silas) must be a very handsome man, Mrs. Rusk. Don't you think so?'' (I)
I continued.

``He (Silas) _was_, my dear--yes; but it is forty years since that was painted--the date is there in the corner, in the shadow that comes from his (Silas) foot, and forty years, I can tell you, makes a change in most of us;' and Mrs. Rusk laughed, in cynical good-humour.

There was a little pause, both still looking on the handsome man in top-boots, and I said--

``And why, Mrs. Rusk, is papa always so sad about Uncle Silas?'' (I)

``What's that, child?'' (father)
said my father's voice, very near. I looked round, with a start, and flushed and faltered, receding a step from him (father).

``No harm, dear. You have said nothing wrong,'' (he)
he (father) said gently, observing my alarm.
``You said I was always sad, I think, about Uncle Silas. Well, I don't know how you gather that; but if I were, I will now tell you, it would not be unnatural. Your uncle is a man of great talents, great faults, and great wrongs. His (uncle) talents have not availed him (uncle); his (uncle) faults are long ago repented of; and his (uncle) wrongs I believe he (uncle) feels less than I do, but they are deep. Did she (uncle) say any more, madam?'' (he)
he (father) demanded abruptly of Mrs. Rusk.

``Nothing, sir,'' (Mrs. Rusk/Rusk)
with a stiff little courtesy, answered Mrs. Rusk, who stood in awe of him (father).

``And there is no need, child,'' (he)
he (father) continued, addressing himself to me, `that you should think more of him (father) at present. Clear your head of Uncle Silas. One day, perhaps, you will know him (Silas)--yes, very well--and understand how villains have injured him (Silas).

Then my father retired, and at the door he (father) said--

``Mrs. Rusk, a word, if you please,'' (he)
beckoning to that lady, who trotted after him (father) to the library.

I think he (father) then laid some injunction upon the housekeeper, which was transmitted by her (housekeeper) to Mary Quince, for from that time forth I could never lead either to talk with me about Uncle Silas. They let me talk on, but were reserved and silent themselves, and seemed embarrassed, and Mrs. Rusk sometimes pettish and angry, when I pressed for information.

Thus curiosity was piqued; and round the slender portrait in the leather pantaloons and top-boots gathered many-coloured circles of mystery, and the handsome features seemed to smile down upon my baffled curiosity with a provoking significance.

Why is it that this form of ambition--curiosity--which entered into the temptation of our first parent, is so specially hard to resist? Knowledge is power--and power of one sort or another is the secret lust of human souls; and here is, beside the sense of exploration, the undefinable interest of a story, and above all, something forbidden, to stimulate the contumacious appetite.

CHAPTER III

_A NEW FACE_

I think it was about a fortnight after that conversation in which my father had expressed his (father) opinion, and given me the mysterious charge about the old oak cabinet in his (father) library, as already detailed, that I was one night sitting at the great drawing-room window, lost in the melancholy reveries of night, and in admiration of the moonlighted scene. I was the only occupant of the room; and the lights near the fire, at its farther end, hardly reached to the window at which I sat.

The shorn grass sloped gently downward from the windows till it met the broad level on which stood, in clumps, or solitarily scattered, some of the noblest timber in England. Hoar in the moonbeams stood those graceful trees casting their moveless shadows upon the grass, and in the background crowning the undulations of the distance, in masses, were piled those woods among which lay the solitary tomb where the remains of my beloved mother rested.

The air was still. The silvery vapour hung serenely on the far horizon, and the frosty stars blinked brightly. Everyone knows the effect of such a scene on a mind already saddened. Fancies and regrets float mistily in the dream, and the scene affects us with a strange mixture of memory and anticipation, like some sweet old air heard in the distance. As my eyes rested on those, to me, funereal but glorious woods, which formed the background of the picture, my thoughts recurred to my father's mysterious intimations and the image of the approaching visitor; and the thought of the unknown journey saddened me.

In all that concerned his (visitor) religion, from very early association, there was to me something of the unearthly and spectral.

When my dear mamma died I was not nine years old; and I remember, two days before the funeral, there came to Knowl, where she (me) died, a thin little man, with large black eyes, and a very grave, dark face.

He (man) was shut up a good deal with my dear father, who was in deep affliction; and Mrs. Rusk used to say,

``It is rather odd to see him (uncle) praying with that little scarecrow from London, and good Mr. Clay ready at call, in the village; much good that little black whipper-snapper will do him (Clay)!'' (Mrs. Rusk/Rusk)

With that little black man, on the day after the funeral, I was sent out, for some reason, for a walk; my governess was ill, I know, and there was confusion in the house, and I dare say the maids made as much of a holiday as they could.

I remember feeling a sort of awe of this little dark man; but I was not afraid of him (man), for he (man) was gentle, though sad--and seemed kind. He (man) led me into the garden--the Dutch garden, we used to call it--with a balustrade, and statues at the farther front, laid out in a carpet-pattern of brilliantly-coloured flowers. We came down the broad flight of Caen stone steps into this, and we walked in silence to the balustrade. The base was too high at the spot where we reached it for me to see over; but holding my hand, he (man) said,

``Look through that, my child. Well, you can't; but _I_ can see beyond it--shall I tell you what? I see ever so much. I see a cottage with a steep roof, that looks like gold in the sunlight; there are tall trees throwing soft shadows round it, and flowering shrubs, I can't say what, only the colours are beautiful, growing by the walls and windows, and two little children are playing among the stems of the trees, and we are on our way there, and in a few minutes shall be under those trees ourselves, and talking to those little children. Yet now to me it is but a picture in my brain, and to you but a story told by me, which you believe. Come, dear; let us be going.'' (he)

So we descended the steps at the right, and side by side walked along the grass lane between tall trim walls of evergreens. The way was in deep shadow, for the sun was near the horizon; but suddenly we turned to the left, and there we stood in rich sunlight, among the many objects he (man) had described.

``Is this your house, my little men?'' (he)
he (man) asked of the children--pretty little rosy boys--who assented; and he (man) leaned with his (man) open hand against the stem of one of the trees, and with a grave smile he (man) nodded down to me, saying--

``You see now, and hear, and _feel_ for yourself that both the vision and the story were quite true; but come on, my dear, we have further to go.'' (me)

And relapsing into silence we had a long ramble through the wood, the same on which I was now looking in the distance. Every now and then he (man) made me sit down to rest, and he (man) in a musing solemn sort of way would relate some little story, reflecting, even to my childish mind, a strange suspicion of a spiritual meaning, but different from what honest Mrs. Rusk used to expound to me from the Parables, and, somehow, startling in its very vagueness.

Thus entertained, though a little awfully, I accompanied the dark mysterious little `whipper-snapper' through the woodland glades. We came, to me quite unexpectedly, in the deep sylvan shadows, upon the grey, pillared temple, four-fronted, with a slanting pedestal of lichen-stained steps, the lonely sepulchre in which I had the morning before seen poor mamma laid. At the sight the fountains of my grief reopened, and I cried bitterly, repeating,

``Oh! mamma, mamma, little mamma!'' (I)
and so went on weeping and calling wildly on the deaf and the silent. There was a stone bench some ten steps away from the tomb.

``Sit down beside me, my child,'' (the man)
said the grave man with the black eyes, very kindly and gently.
``Now, what do you see there?'' (he)
he (man) asked, pointing horizontally with his (man) stick towards the centre of the opposite structure.

``Oh, _that_--that place where poor mamma is?'' (unknown)

``Yes, a stone wall with pillars, too high for either you or me to see over. But--'

Here he (you) mentioned a name which I think must have been Swedenborg, from what I afterwards learnt of his (you) tenets and revelations; I only know that it sounded to me like the name of a magician in a fairy tale; I fancied he (magician) lived in the wood which surrounded us, and I began to grow frightened as he (magician) proceeded.

``But Swedenborg sees beyond it, over, and _through_ it, and has told me all that concerns us to know. He (magician) says your mamma is not there.'' (unknown)

``She (fairy) is taken away!'' (I)
I cried, starting up, and with streaming eyes, gazing on the building which, though I stamped my feet in my distraction, I was afraid to approach.
``Oh, _is_ mamma taken away? Where is she (fairy)? Where have they brought her (fairy) to?'' (I)

I was uttering unconsciously very nearly the question with which Mary, in the grey of that wondrous morning on which she (Mary) stood by the empty sepulchre, accosted the figure standing near.

``Your mamma is alive but too far away to see or hear us. Swedenborg, standing here, can see and hear her (fairy), and tells me all he (magician) sees, just as I told you in the garden about the little boys and the cottage, and the trees and flowers which you could not see, but you believed in when _I_ told you. So I can tell you now as I did then; and as we are both, I hope, walking on to the same place just as we did to the trees and cottage. You will surely see with your own eyes how true the description is which I give you.'' (I)

I was very frightened, for I feared that when he (man) had done his (man) narrative we were to walk on through the wood into that place of wonders and of shadows where the dead were visible.

He (man) leaned his (man) elbow on his (man) knee, and his (man) forehead on his (man) hand, which shaded his (man) downcast eyes. In that attitude he (man) described to me a beautiful landscape, radiant with a wondrous light, in which, rejoicing, my mother moved along an airy path, ascending among mountains of fantastic height, and peaks, melting in celestial colouring into the air, and peopled with human beings translated into the same image, beauty, and splendour. And when he (man) had ended his (man) relation, he (man) rose, took my hand, and smiling gently down on my pale, wondering face, he (man) said the same words he (man) had spoken before--

``Come, dear, let us go.'' (he)

``Oh! no, no, _no_--not now,'' (I)
I said, resisting, and very much frightened.

``Home, I mean, dear. We cannot walk to the place I have described. We can only reach it through the gate of death, to which we are all tending, young and old, with sure steps.'' (unknown)

``And where is the gate of death?'' (I)
I asked in a sort of whisper, as we walked together, holding his (man) hand, and looking stealthily. He (man) smiled sadly and said--

``When, sooner or later, the time comes, as Hagar's eyes were opened in the wilderness, and she (it) beheld the fountain of water, so shall each of us see the door open before us, and enter in and be refreshed.'' (He)

For a long time following this walk I was very nervous; more so for the awful manner in which Mrs. Rusk received my statement--with stern lips and upturned hands and eyes, and an angry expostulation:

``I do wonder at you, Mary Quince, letting the child walk into the wood with that limb of darkness. It is a mercy he (Hagar) did not show her (Quince) the devil, or frighten her (Quince) out of her (Quince) senses, in that lonely place!'' (Mrs. Rusk/Rusk)

Of these Swedenborgians, indeed, I know no more than I might learn from good Mrs. Rusk's very inaccurate talk. Two or three of them crossed in the course of my early life, like magic-lantern figures, the disk of my very circumscribed observation. All outside was and is darkness. I once tried to read one of their books upon the future state--heaven and hell; but I grew after a day or two so nervous that I laid it aside. It is enough for me to know that their founder either saw or fancied he (founder) saw amazing visions, which, so far from superseding, confirmed and interpreted the language of the Bible; and as dear papa accepted their ideas, I am happy in thinking that they did not conflict with the supreme authority of holy writ.

Leaning on my hand, I was now looking upon that solemn wood, white and shadowy in the moonlight, where, for a long time after that ramble with the visionary, I fancied the gate of death, hidden only by a strange glamour, and the dazzling land of ghosts, were situate; and I suppose these earlier associations gave to my reverie about my father's coming visitor a wilder and a sadder tinge.

CHAPTER IV

_MADAME DE LA ROUGIERRE_

On a sudden, on the grass before me, stood an odd figure--a very tall woman in grey draperies, nearly white under the moon, courtesying extraordinarily low, and rather fantastically.

I stared in something like a horror upon the large and rather hollow features which I did not know, smiling very unpleasantly on me; and the moment it was plain that I saw her (woman), the grey woman began gobbling and cackling shrilly--I could not distinctly hear _what_ through the window--and gesticulating oddly with her (woman) long hands and arms.

As she (woman) drew near the window, I flew to the fireplace, and rang the bell frantically, and seeing her (woman) still there, and fearing that she (woman) might break into the room, I flew out of the door, very much frightened, and met Branston the butler in the lobby.

``There's a woman at the window!'' (I)
I gasped; `turn her (woman) away, please.''

If I had said a man, I suppose fat Branston would have summoned and sent forward a detachment of footmen. As it was, he (Branston) bowed gravely, with a--

``Yes, 'm--shall,

``m.'' (he)

And with an air of authority approached the window.

I don't think that he (Branston) was pleasantly impressed himself by the first sight of our visitor, for he (Branston) stopped short some steps of the window, and demanded rather sternly--

``What ye doin' there, woman?'' (he)

To this summons, her (woman) answer, which occupied a little time, was inaudible to me. But Branston replied--

``I wasn't aware, ma'am; I heerd nothin'; if you'll go round _that_ way, you'll see the hall-door steps, and I'll speak to the master, and do as he (master) shall order.'' (Branston)

The figure said something and pointed.

``Yes, that's it, and ye can't miss the door.'' (Mr.)

And Mr. Branston returned slowly down the long room, and halted with out-turned pumps and a grave inclination before me, and the faintest amount of interrogation in the announcement--

``Please, 'm, she (woman) says she (woman)'s the governess.'' (me)

``The governess! _What_ governess?'' (Branston)

Branston was too well-bred to smile, and he (Branston) said thoughtfully--

``P'raps, 'm, I'd best ask the master?'' (he)

To which I assented, and away strode the flat pumps of the butler to the library.

I stood breathless in the hall. Every girl at my age knows how much is involved in such an advent. I also heard Mrs. Rusk, in a minute or two more, emerge I suppose from the study. She (Rusk) walked quickly, and muttered sharply to herself--an evil trick, in which she (Rusk) indulged when much `put about.'' I should have been glad of a word with her (Rusk); but I fancied she (Rusk) was vexed, and would not have talked satisfactorily. She (Rusk) did not, however, come my way; merely crossing the hall with her (Rusk) quick, energetic step.

Was it really the arrival of a governess? Was that apparition which had impressed me so unpleasantly to take the command of me--to sit alone with me, and haunt me perpetually with her (Rusk) sinister looks and shrilly gabble?

I was just making up my mind to go to Mary Quince, and learn something definite, when I heard my father's step approaching from the library: so I quietly re-entered the drawing-room, but with an anxious and throbbing heart.

When he (father) came in, as usual, he (father) patted me on the head gently, with a kind of smile, and then began his (father) silent walk up and down the room. I was yearning to question him (father) on the point that just then engrossed me so disagreeably; but the awe in which I stood of him (father) forbade.

After a time he (father) stopped at the window, the curtain of which I had drawn, and the shutter partly opened, and he (father) looked out, perhaps with associations of his (father) own, on the scene I had been contemplating.

It was not for nearly an hour after, that my father suddenly, after his (father) wont, in a few words, apprised me of the arrival of Madame de la Rougierre to be my governess, highly recommended and perfectly qualified. My heart sank with a sure presage of ill. I already disliked, distrusted, and feared her (Madame).

I had more than an apprehension of her (Madame) temper and fear of possibly abused authority. The large-featured, smirking phantom, saluting me so oddly in the moonlight, retained ever after its peculiar and unpleasant hold upon my nerves.

``Well, Miss Maud, dear, I hope you'll like your new governess--for it's more than _I_ do, just at present at least,'' (Mrs. Rusk/Rusk)
said Mrs. Rusk, sharply--she (Rusk) was awaiting me in my room.
``I hate them French-women; they're not natural, I think. I gave her (Maud) her (Maud) supper in my room. She (Maud) eats like a wolf, she (Maud) does, the great raw-boned hannimal. I wish you saw her (Maud) in bed as I did. I put her (Maud) next the clock-room--she (Maud)'ll hear the hours betimes, I'm thinking. You never saw such a sight. The great long nose and hollow cheeks of her (Maud), and oogh! such a mouth! I felt a`most like little Red Riding-Hood--I did, Miss.'' (Mary Quince/Mary)

Here honest Mary Quince, who enjoyed Mrs. Rusk's satire, a weapon in which she (Quince) was not herself strong, laughed outright.

``Turn down the bed, Mary. She (Mary)'s very agreeable--she (Mary) is, just now--all new-comers is; but she (Mary) did not get many compliments from me, Miss--no, I rayther think not. I wonder why honest English girls won't answer the gentry for governesses, instead of them gaping, scheming, wicked furriners? Lord forgi' me, I think they're all alike.'' (I)

Next morning I made acquaintance with Madame de la Rougierre. She (Quince) was tall, masculine, a little ghastly perhaps, and draped in purple silk, with a lace cap, and great bands of black hair, too thick and black, perhaps, to correspond quite naturally with her (Quince) bleached and sallow skin, her (Quince) hollow jaws, and the fine but grim wrinkles traced about her (Quince) brows and eyelids. ``And how is she (Mary) named--what is Mademoiselle's name?'' (the stranger)
said the tall stranger.

'_Maud_, Madame.''

``Maud!--what pretty name! Eh bien! I am very sure my dear Maud she (Maud) will be very good little girl--is not so?--and I am sure I shall love you vary moche. And what `av you been learning, Maud, my dear cheaile--music, French, German, eh?'' (unknown)

``Yes, a little; and I had just begun the use of the globes when my governess went away.'' (I)

I nodded towards the globes, which stood near her (Maud), as I said this.

``Oh! yes--the globes;' and she (Maud) spun one of them with her (Maud) great hand.

``Je vous expliquerai tout cela à fond.'' (Madame)

Madame de la Rougierre, I found, was always quite ready to explain everything 'à fond;' but somehow her (Maud)

``explications,'' (I)
as she (Maud) termed them, were not very intelligible, and when pressed her (Maud) temper woke up; so that I preferred, after a while, accepting the expositions just as they came.

Madame was on an unusually large scale, a circumstance which made some of her (Maud) traits more startling, and altogether rendered her (Maud), in her (Maud) strange way, more awful in the eyes of a nervous _child,_ I may say, such as I was. She (Maud) used to look at me for a long time sometimes, with the peculiar smile I have mentioned, and a great finger upon her (Maud) lip, like the Eleusinian priestess on the vase.

She (Maud) would sit, too, sometimes for an hour together, looking into the fire or out of the window, plainly seeing nothing, and with an odd, fixed look of something like triumph--very nearly a smile--on her (Maud) cunning face.

She (Maud) was by no means a pleasant _gouvernante_ for a nervous girl of my years. Sometimes she (girl) had accesses of a sort of hilarity which frightened me still more than her (girl) graver moods, and I will describe these by-and-by.

CHAPTER V

_SIGHTS AND NOISES_

There is not an old house in England of which the servants and young people who live in it do not cherish some traditions of the ghostly. Knowl has its shadows, noises, and marvellous records. Rachel Ruthyn, the beauty of Queen Anne's time, who died of grief for the handsome Colonel Norbrooke, who was killed in the Low Countries, walks the house by night, in crisp and sounding silks. She (Anne) is not seen, only heard. The tapping of her (Anne) high-heeled shoes, the sweep and rustle of her (Anne) brocades, her (Anne) sighs as she (Anne) pauses in the galleries, near the bed-room doors; and sometimes, on stormy nights, her (Anne) sobs.

There is, beside, the `link-man', a lank, dark-faced, black-haired man, in a sable suit, with a link or torch in his (man) hand. It usually only smoulders, with a deep red glow, as he (man) visits his (man) beat. The library is one of the rooms he (man) sees to. Unlike

``Lady Rachel,'' (the maids)
as the maids called her (Anne), he (man) is seen only, never heard. His (man) steps fall noiseless as shadows on floor and carpet. The lurid glow of his (man) smouldering torch imperfectly lights his (man) figure and face, and, except when much perturbed, his (man) link never blazes. On those occasions, however, as he (man) goes his (man) rounds, he (man) ever and anon whirls it around his (man) head, and it bursts into a dismal flame. This is a fearful omen, and always portends some direful crisis or calamity. It occurs, only once or twice in a century.

I don't know whether Madame had heard anything of these phenomena; but she (man) did report which very much frightened me and Mary Quince. She (Quince) asked us who walked in the gallery on which her (Quince) bed-room opened, making a rustling with her (Quince) dress, and going down the stairs, and breathing long breaths here and there. Twice, she (Quince) said, she (Quince) had stood at her (Quince) door in the dark, listening to these sounds, and once she (Quince) called to know who it was. There was no answer, but the person plainly turned back, and hurried towards her (Quince) with an unnatural speed, which made her (Quince) jump within her (Quince) door and shut it.

When first such tales are told, they excite the nerves of the young and the ignorant intensely. But the special effect, I have found, soon wears out The tale simply takes it's place with the rest. It was with Madame's narrative.

About a week after its relation, I had my experience of a similar sort. Mary Quince went down-stairs for a night-light, leaving me in bed, a candle burning in the room, and being tired, I fell asleep before her (Quince) return. When I awoke the candle had been extinguished. But I heard a step softly approaching. I jumped up--quite forgetting the ghost, and thinking only of Mary Quince--and opened the door, expecting to see the light of her (Mary) candle. Instead, all was dark, and near me I heard the fall of a bare foot on the oak floor. It was as if some one had stumbled. I said,

``Mary,'' (I)
but no answer came, only a rustling of clothes and a breathing at the other side of the gallery, which passed off towards the upper staircase. I turned into my room, freezing with horror, and clapt my door. The noise wakened Mary Quince, who had returned and gone to her (Quince) bed half an hour before.

About a fortnight after this, Mary Quince, a very veracious spinster, reported to me, that having got up to fix the window, which was rattling, at about four o'clock in the morning, she (Quince) saw a light shining from the library window. She (Quince) could swear to its being a strong light, streaming through the chinks of the shutter, and moving. No doubt the link was waved about his (Quince) head by the angry

``link-man.'' (I)

These strange occurrences helped, I think, just then to make me nervous, and prepared the way for the odd sort of ascendency which, through my sense of the mysterious and super-natural, that repulsive Frenchwoman was gradually, and it seemed without effort, establishing over me.

Some dark points of her (Frenchwoman) character speedily emerged from the prismatic mist with which she (Frenchwoman) had enveloped it.

Mrs. Rusk's observation about the agreeability of new-comers I found to be true; for as Madame began to lose that character, her (Rusk) good-humour abated very perceptibly, and she (Rusk) began to show gleams of another sort of temper, that was lurid and dangerous.

Notwithstanding this, she (Rusk) was in the habit of always having her (Rusk) Bible open by her (Rusk), and was austerely attentive at morning and evening services, and asked my father, with great humility, to lend her (Rusk) some translations of Swedenborg's books, which she (Rusk) laid much to heart.

When we went out for our walk, if the weather were bad we generally made our promenade up and down the broad terrace in front of the windows. Sullen and malign at times she (Rusk) used to look, and as suddenly she (Rusk) would pat me on the shoulder caressingly, and smile with a grotesque benignity, asking tenderly,

``Are you fatigue, ma chère?'' (me)
or
``Are you cold-a, dear Maud?'' (me)

At first these abrupt transitions puzzled me, sometimes half frightened me, savouring, I fancied, of insanity. The key, however, was accidentally supplied, and I found that these accesses of demonstrative affection were sure to supervene whenever my father's face was visible through the library windows.

I did not know well what to make of this woman, whom I feared with a vein of superstitious dread. I hated being alone with her (woman) after dusk in the school-room. She (woman) would sometimes sit for half an hour at a time, with her (woman) wide mouth drawn down at the corners, and a scowl, looking into the fire. If she (woman) saw me looking at her (woman), she (woman) would change all this on the instant, affect a sort of languor, and lean her (woman) head upon her (woman) hand, and ultimately have recourse to her (woman) Bible. But I fancied she (woman) did not read, but pursued her (woman) own dark ruminations, for I observed that the open book might often lie for half an hour or more under her (woman) eyes and yet the leaf never turned.

I should have been glad to be assured that she (woman) prayed when on her (woman) knees, or read when that book was before her (woman); I should have felt that she (woman) was more canny and human. As it was, those external pieties made a suspicion of a hollow contrast with realities that helped to scare me; yet it was but a suspicion--I could not be certain.

Our rector and the curate, with whom she (woman) was very gracious, and anxious about my collects and catechism, had an exalted opinion of her (woman). In public places her (woman) affection for me was always demonstrative.

In like manner she (woman) contrived conferences with my father. ``Wat wicked cheaile!'' (Madame)
moaned Madame, demurely.

It was a long one, and in a state of profound irritation I got through the task.

Mrs. Rusk hated her (Rusk). She (Rusk) said she (Rusk) stole wine and brandy whenever the opportunity offered--that she (Rusk) was always asking her (Rusk) for such stimulants and pretending pains in her (Rusk) stomach. Man's estimate of woman is higher than woman's own. Perhaps in their relations to men they are generally more trustworthy--perhaps woman's is the juster, and the other an appointed illusion. I don't know; but so it is ordained.

CHAPTER VII

_CHURCH SCARSDALE_

I think all the females of our household, except Mrs. Rusk, who was at open feud with her (Rusk) and had only room for the fiercer emotions, were more or less afraid of this inauspicious foreigner.

Church Scarsdale is a very pretty and odd scene. The slightly undulating sheep-walk dips suddenly into a wide glen, in the lap of which, by a bright, winding rill, rise from the sward the ruins of a small abbey, with a few solemn trees scattered round. The crows' nests hung untenanted in the trees; the birds were foraging far away from their roosts. The very cattle had forsaken the place. It was solitude itself.

CHAPTER VIII

_THE SMOKER_

Three years later I learned--in a way she (couple) probably little expected, and then did not much care about--what really occurred there. CHAPTER IX

_MONICA KNOLLYS_

``ansom.'' (he)

Just at that moment Captain Oakley joined us. He (Oakley) was my first actual vision of that awful and distant world of fashion, of whose splendours I had already read something in the three-volumed gospel of the circulating library.

Handsome, elegant, with features almost feminine, and soft, wavy, black hair, whiskers and moustache, he (Oakley) was altogether such a knight as I had never beheld, or even fancied, at Knowl--a hero of another species, and from the region of the demigods. I did not then perceive that coldness of the eye, and cruel curl of the voluptuous lip--only a suspicion, yet enough to indicate the profligate man, and savouring of death unto death.

But I was young, and had not yet the direful knowledge of good and evil that comes with years; and he (man) was so very handsome, and talked in a way that was so new to me, and was so much more charming than the well-bred converse of the humdrum county families with whom I had occasionally sojourned for a week at a time.

It came out incidentally that his (man) leave of absence was to expire the day after to-morrow. A Lilliputian pang of disappointment followed this announcement. Already I was sorry to lose him (man). So soon we begin to make a property of what pleases us.

I was shy, but not awkward. I was flattered by the attention of this amusing, perhaps rather fascinating, young man of the world; and he (man) plainly addressed himself with diligence to amuse and please me. _LADY KNOLLYS REMOVES A COVERLET_

CHAPTER XII

_A CURIOUS CONVERSATION_

We each had another cup of tea, and were silent for awhile.

CHAPTER XIII

_BEFORE AND AFTER BREAKFAST_

Next morning early I visited my favourite full-length portrait in the chocolate coat and top-boots. Scanty as had been my cousin Monica's notes upon this dark and eccentric biography, they were everything to me. A soul had entered that enchanted form. Truth had passed by with her (Monica) torch, and a sad light shone for a moment on that enigmatic face.

There stood the _roué_--the duellist--and, with all his (cousin) faults, the hero too! In that dark large eye lurked the profound and fiery enthusiasm of his (cousin) ill-starred passion. In the thin but exquisite lip I read the courage of the paladin, who would have `fought his (cousin) way,'' though single-handed, against all the magnates of his (cousin) county, and by ordeal of battle have purged the honour of the Ruthyns. There in that delicate half-sarcastic tracery of the nostril I detected the intellectual defiance which had politically isolated Silas Ruthyn and opposed him (cousin) to the landed oligarchy of his (cousin) county, whose retaliation had been a hideous slander. There, too, and on his (cousin) brows and lip, I traced the patience of a cold disdain. I could now see him (cousin) as he (cousin) was--the prodigal, the hero, and the martyr. I stood gazing on him (cousin) with a girlish interest and admiration. There was indignation, there was pity, there was hope. Some day it might come to pass that I, girl as I was, might contribute by word or deed towards the vindication of that long-suffering, gallant, and romantic prodigal. It was a flicker of the Joan of Arc inspiration, common, I fancy, to many girls. I little then imagined how profoundly and strangely involved my uncle's fate would one day become with mine.

I was interrupted by Captain Oakley's voice at the window. He (Captain) was leaning on the window-sill, and looking in with a smile--the window being open, the morning sunny, and his (Captain) cap lifted in his (Captain) hand.

``Good-morning, Miss Ruthyn. What a charming old place! quite the setting for a romance; such timber, and this really _beautiful_ house. I _do_ so like these white and black houses--wonderful old things. By-the-by, you treated us very badly last night--you did, indeed; upon my word, now, it really was too bad--running away, and drinking tea with Lady Knollys--so she (Knollys) says. I really--I should not like to tell you how very savage I felt, particularly considering how very short my time is.'' (I)

I was a shy, but not a giggling country miss. I knew I was an heiress; I knew I was somebody. I was not the least bit in the world conceited, but I think this knowledge helped to give me a certain sense of security and self-possession, which might have been mistaken for dignity or simplicity. I am sure I looked at him (Captain) with a fearless enquiry, for he (Captain) answered my thoughts.

``I do really assure you, Miss Ruthyn, I am quite serious; you have no idea how very much we have missed you.'' (a fool)

There was a little pause, and, like a fool, I lowered my eyes, and blushed.

``I--I was thinking of leaving today; I am so unfortunate--my leave is just out--it is so unlucky; but I don't quite know whether my aunt Knollys will allow me to go.'' (I)

'_I_?--certainly, my dear Charlie, _I_ don't want you at all,

'' exclaimed a voice--Lady Knollys's--briskly, from an open window close by; `what could put that in your head, dear?'' (I)

CHAPTER XIV

_ANGRY WORDS_

CHAPTER XV

_A WARNING_

I sat still, listening and wondering, and wondering and listening; but I ought to have known that no sound could reach me where I was from my father's study. (she)

Of Madame de la Rougierre I had nothing at first particular to remark. Its intensity I cannot now even myself recall. But it overshadowed me perpetually--a care, an alarm. It lay down with me at night and got up with me in the morning, tinting and disturbing my dreams, and making my daily life terrible. I wonder now that I lived through the ordeal. The torment was secret and incessant, and kept my mind in unintermitting activity.

CHAPTER XVI

_DOCTOR BRYERLY LOOKS IN_

But I was immovable. It was neither obstinacy nor caprice, but a profound fear that governed me. I was then afraid--yes, _afraid_. Afraid of _what_? Well, of going with Madame de la Rougierre to Church Scarsdale that day. That was all. And I believe that instinct was true.

She (lady) turned a bitter glance toward Church Scarsdale, and bit her (lady) lip. She (lady) saw that she (lady) must give it up. A shadow hung upon her (lady) drab features. CHAPTER XVII

_AN ADVENTURE_

For many days after our quarrel, Madame hardly spoke to me. As for lessons, I was not much troubled with them. It was plain, too, that my father had spoken to her (I), for she (I) never after that day proposed our extending our walks beyond the precincts of Knowl.

Knowl, however, was a very considerable territory, and it was possible for a much better pedestrian than I to tire herself effectually, without passing its limits. So we took occasionally long walks.

After some weeks of sullenness, during which for days at a time she (I) hardly spoke to me, and seemed lost in dark and evil abstraction, she (I) once more, and somewhat suddenly, recovered her (I) spirits, and grew quite friendly. Her (I) gaieties and friendliness were not reassuring, and in my mind presaged approaching mischief and treachery. The days were shortening to the wintry span. The edge of the red sun had already touched the horizon as Madame and I, overtaken at the warren by his (me) last beams, were hastening homeward.

A narrow carriage-road traverses this wild region of the park, to which a distant gate gives entrance. On descending into this unfrequented road, I was surprised to see a carriage standing there. A thin, sly postilion, with that pert, turned-up nose which the old caricaturist Woodward used to attribute to the gentlemen of Tewkesbury, was leaning on his (Woodward) horses, and looked hard at me as I passed. A lady who sat within looked out, with an extra-fashionable bonnet on, and also treated us to a stare. Very pink and white cheeks she (lady) had, very black glossy hair and bright eyes--fat, bold, and rather cross, she (lady) looked--and in her (lady) bold way she (lady) examined us curiously as we passed.

I mistook the situation. It had once happened before that an intending visitor at Knowl had entered the place by that park-road, and lost several hours in a vain search for the house.

``Ask him (man), Madame, whether they want to go to the house; I dare say they have missed their way,'' (I.)
whispered I.

Hallo! there, mild `n, I say, stop packin'' (unknown)
.'' This was to the ill-favoured person with the broken nose.

As it happened, my father met us in the hall. He (father) was perfectly transported with fury on hearing from Madame what had happened, and set out at once, with some of the servants, in the hope of intercepting the party at the park-gate.

Here was a new agitation; for my father did not return for nearly three hours, and I could not conjecture what might be occurring during the period of his (father) absence. My alarm was greatly increased by the arrival in the interval of poor Bill, the under-gamekeeper, very much injured.

Seeing that he (Bill) was determined to intercept their retreat, the three men had set upon him (Bill), wrested his (Bill) gun, which exploded in the struggle, from him (Bill), and beat him (Bill) savagely. I mention these particulars, because they convinced everybody that there was something specially determined and ferocious in the spirit of the party, and that the fracas was no mere frolic, but the result of a predetermined plan.

My father had not succeeded in overtaking them. He (father) traced them to the Lugton Station, where they had taken the railway, and no one could tell him (father) in what direction the carriage and posthorses had driven.

Madame was, or affected to be, very much shattered by what had occurred. ``Wat fool you were! so disobedient and obstinate; if you `ad done wat _I_ say, then we should av been quaite safe; those persons they were tipsy, and there is nothing so dangerous as to quarrel with tipsy persons; I would `av brought you quaite safe--the lady she (lady) seem so nice and quaite, and we should `av been safe with her (lady)--there would `av been nothing absolutely; but instead you would scream and pooshe, and so they grow quite wild, and all the impertinence and violence follow of course; and that a poor Bill--all his (Bill) beating and danger to his (Bill) life it is cause entairely by you.'' (she)

I was crying and wringing my hands, and turning from side to side, at my wits' ends, and honest Mary Quince in vain endevoured to quiet and comfort me.

CHAPTER XVIII

_A MIDNIGHT VISITOR_

The frightful warnings of Lady Knollys haunted me too. Was there no escape from the dreadful companion whom fate had assigned me? I made up my mind again and again to speak to my father and urge her (Knollys) removal. In other things he (father) indulged me; here, however, he (father) met me drily and sternly, and it was plain that he (father) fancied I was under my cousin Monica's influence, and also that he (father) had secret reasons for persisting in an opposite course. Just then I had a gay, odd letter from Lady Knollys, from some country house in Shropshire. Not a word about Captain Oakley. My eye skimmed its pages in search of that charmed name. With a peevish feeling I tossed the sheet upon the table. Inwardly I thought how ill-natured and unwomanly it was.

After a time, however, I read it, and found the letter very good-natured. She (Knollys) had received a note from papa. He (papa) had `had the impudence to forgive _her (Knollys)_ for _his (papa)_ impertinence.'' But for my sake she (Knollys) meant, notwithstanding this aggravation, really to pardon him (papa); and whenever she (Knollys) had a disengaged week, to accept his (papa) invitation to Knowl, from whence she (Knollys) was resolved to whisk me off to London, where, though I was too young to be presented at Court and come out, I might yet--besides having the best masters and a good excuse for getting rid of Medusa--see a great deal that would amuse and surprise me.

``Great news, I suppose, from Lady Knollys?'' (Madame)
said Madame, who always knew who in the house received letters by the post, and by an intuition from whom they came.

``Two letters--you and your papa. She (Lady) is quite well, I hope?'' (unknown)

``Quite well, thank you, Madame.'' (unknown)

Some fishing questions, dropped from time to time, fared no better. And as usual, when she (Knollys) was foiled even in a trifle, she (Knollys) became sullen and malignant.

That night, when my father and I were alone, he (father) suddenly closed the book he (father) had been reading, and said--

``I heard from Monica Knollys to-day. I always liked poor Monnie; and though she (Knollys)'s no witch, and very wrong-headed at times, yet now and then she (Knollys) does say a thing that's worth weighing. Did she (Knollys) ever talk to you of a time, Maud, when you are to be your own mistress?'' (he)

``No,'' (I)
I answered, a little puzzled, and looking straight in his (father) rugged, kindly face.

``Well, I thought she (mistress) might--she (mistress)'s a rattle, you know--always _was_ a rattle, and that sort of people say whatever comes uppermost. But that's a subject for me, and more than once, Maud, it has puzzled me.'' (He)

He (father) sighed.

``Come with me to the study, little Maud.'' (he)

So, he (father) carrying a candle, we crossed the lobby, and marched together through the passage, which at night always seemed a little awesome, darkly wainscoted, uncheered by the cross-light from the hall, which was lost at the turn, leading us away from the frequented parts of the house to that misshapen and lonely room about which the traditions of the nursery and the servants' hall had had so many fearful stories to recount.

I think my father had intended making some disclosure to me on reaching this room. If so, he (father) changed his (father) mind, or at least postponed his (father) intention.

He (father) had paused before the cabinet, respecting the key of which he (father) had given me so strict a charge, and I think he (father) was going to explain himself more fully than he (father) had done. But he (father) went on, instead, to the table where his (father) desk, always jealously locked, was placed, and having lighted the candles which stood by it, he (father) glanced at me, and said--

``You must wait a little, Maud; I shall have something to say to you. Take this candle and amuse yourself with a book meanwhile.'' (me)

I was accustomed to obey in silence. I chose a volume of engravings, and ensconced myself in a favourite nook in which I had often passed a half-hour similarly. This was a deep recess by the fireplace, fenced on the other side by a great old escritoir. Into this I drew a stool, and, with candle and book, I placed myself snugly in the narrow chamber. Every now and then I raised my eyes and saw my father either writing or ruminating, as it seemed to me, very anxiously at his (father) desk.

Time wore on--a longer time than he (father) had intended, and still he (father) continued absorbed at his (father) desk. Gradually I grew sleepy, and as I nodded, the book and room faded away, and pleasant little dreams began to gather round me, and so I went off into a deep slumber.

It must have lasted long, for when I wakened my candle had burnt out; my father, having quite forgotten me, was gone, and the room was dark and deserted. I felt cold and a little stiff, and for some seconds did not know where I was.

I had been wakened, I suppose, by a sound which I now distinctly heard, to my great terror, approaching. There was a rustling; there was a breathing. I heard a creaking upon the plank that always creaked when walked upon in the passage. I held my breath and listened, and coiled myself up in the innermost recess of my little chamber.

Sudden and sharp, a light shone in from the nearly-closed study door. It shone angularly on the ceiling like a letter L reversed. There was a pause. Then some one knocked softly at the door, which after another pause was slowly pushed open. I expected, I think, to see the dreaded figure of the linkman. I was scarcely less frightened to see that of Madame de la Rougierre. She (I) was dressed in a sort of grey silk, which she (I) called her (I) Chinese silk--precisely as she (I) had been in the daytime. In fact, I do not think she (I) had undressed. She (I) had no shoes on. Otherwise her (I) toilet was deficient in nothing. Her (I) wide mouth was grimly closed, and she (I) stood scowling into the room with a searching and pallid scrutiny, the candle held high above her (I) head at the full stretch of her (I) arm.

Placed as I was in a deep recess, and in a seat hardly raised above the level of the floor, I escaped her (I), although it seemed to me for some seconds, as I gazed on this spectre, that our eyes actually met.

I sat without breathing or winking, staring upon the formidable image which with upstretched arm, and the sharp lights and hard shadows thrown upon her (I) corrugated features, looked like a sorceress watching for the effect of a spell.

She (I) was plainly listening intensely. Unconsciously she (I) had drawn her (I) lower lip altogether between her (I) teeth, and I well remember what a deathlike and idiotic look the contortion gave her (I). My terror lest she (I) should discover me amounted to positive agony. She (I) rolled her (I) eyes stealthily from corner to corner of the room, and listened with her (I) neck awry at the door.

Then to my father's desk she (I) went. To my great relief, her (I) back was towards me. She (I) stooped over it, with the candle close by; I saw her (I) try a key--it could be nothing else--and I heard her (I) blow through the wards to clear them.

Then, again, she (I) listened at the door, candle in hand, and then with long tiptoe steps came back, and papa's desk in another moment was open, and Madame cautiously turning over the papers it contained.

Twice or thrice she (I) paused, glided to the door, and listened again intently with her (I) head near the ground, and then returned and continued her (I) search, peeping into papers one after another, tolerably methodically, and reading some quite through.

While this felonious business was going on, I was freezing with fear lest she (I) should accidentally look round and her (I) eyes light on me; for I could not say what she (I) might not do rather than have her (I) crime discovered.

Sometimes she (I) would read a paper twice over; sometimes a whisper no louder than the ticking of a watch, sometimes a brief chuckle under her (I) breath, bespoke the interest with which here and there a letter or a memorandum was read.

For about half an hour, I think, this went on; but at the time it seemed to me all but interminable. On a sudden she (I) raised her (I) head and listened for a moment, replaced the papers deftly, closed the desk without noise, except for the tiny click of the lock, extinguished the candle, and rustled stealthily out of the room, leaving in the darkness the malign and hag-like face on which the candle had just shone still floating filmy in the dark.

Why did I remain silent and motionless while such an outrage was being committed? If, instead of being a very nervous girl, preoccupied with an undefinable terror of that wicked woman, I had possessed courage and presence of mind, I dare say I might have given an alarm, and escaped from the room without the slightest risk. But so it was; I could no more stir than the bird who, cowering under its ivy, sees the white owl sailing back and forward under its predatory cruise.

Not only during her (woman) presence, but for more than an hour after, I remained cowering in my hiding-place, and afraid to stir, lest she (woman) might either be lurking in the neighborhood, or return and surprise me.

You will not be astonished, that after a night so passed I was ill and feverish in the morning. To my horror, Madame de la Rougierre came to visit me at my bedside. Not a trace of guilty consciousness of what had passed during the night was legible in her (woman) face. She (woman) had no sign of late watching, and her (woman) toilet was exemplary.

As she (woman) sat smiling by me, full of anxious and affectionate enquiry, and smoothed the coverlet with her (woman) great felonious hand, I could quite comprehend the dreadful feeling with which the deceived husband in the ``Arabian Nights' met his (mistress) ghoul wife, after his (mistress) nocturnal discovery.

Ill as I was, I got up and found my father in that room which adjoined his (mistress) bedchamber. He (mistress) perceived, I am sure, by my looks, that something unusual had happened. I shut the door, and came close beside his (mistress) chair.

``Oh, papa, I have such a thing to tell you!'' (I)
I forgot to call him (husband)
``Sir.'' (him)
``A secret; and you won't say who told you? Will you come down to the study?'' (He)

He (husband) looked hard at me, got up, and kissing my forehead, said--

``Don't be frightened, Maud; I venture to say it is a mare's nest; at all events, my child, we will take care that no danger reaches you; come, child.'' (me)

And by the hand he (husband) led me to the study. When the door was shut, and we had reached the far end of the room next the window, I said, but in a low tone, and holding his (husband) arm fast--

``Oh, sir, you don't know what a dreadful person we have living with us--Madame de la Rougierre, I mean. Don't let her (Maud) in if she (Maud) comes; she (Maud) would guess what I am telling you, and one way or another I am sure she (Maud) would kill me.'' (I)

``Tut, tut, child. You _must_ know that's nonsense,'' (he)
he (husband) said, looking pale and stern.

``Oh no, papa. I am horribly frightened, and Lady Knollys thinks so too.'' (unknown)

``Ha! I dare say; one fool makes many. We all know what Monica thinks.'' (unknown)

``But I _saw_ it, papa. She (Monica) stole your key last night, and opened your desk, and read all your papers.'' (unknown)

``Stole my key!'' (father)
said my father, staring at me perplexed, but at the same instant producing it.
``Stole it! Why here it is!'' (unknown)

``Did she (Monica) remove any paper?'' (father)

Directions which, coming from another person would have had no great weight, were spoken by my father with an earnest look and a weight of emphasis that made them irresistibly impressive, and I went away with the seal of silence upon my lips.

``Sit down, Maud, _there_. You have not been very happy with Madame de la Rougierre. It is time you were relieved. This occurrence decides it.'' (He)

He (father) rang the bell.

``Tell Madame de la Rougierre that I request the honour of seeing her (Maud) for a few minutes here.'' (father)

My father's communications to her (father) were always equally ceremonious. In a few minutes there was a knock at the door, and the same figure, smiling, courtesying, that had scared me on the threshold last night, like the spirit of evil, presented itself.

My father rose, and Madame having at his (father) request taken a chair opposite, looking, as usual in his (father) presence, all amiability, he (father) proceeded at once to the point.

``Madame de la Rougierre, I have to request you that you will give me the key now in your possession, which unlocks this desk of mine.'' (he)

With which termination he (father) tapped his (father) gold pencil-case suddenly on it.

Madame, who had expected something very different, became instantly so pale, with a dull purplish hue upon her (My) forehead, that, especially when she (My) had twice essayed with her (My) white lips, in vain, to answer, I expected to see her (My) fall in a fit.

She (My) was not looking in his (father) face; her (My) eyes were fixed lower, and her (My) mouth and cheek sucked in, with a strange distortion at one side.

``I cannot comprehend, Monsieur Ruthyn, unless you intend to insult me.'' (she)

``But who dares to say I possess such thing?'' (Madame)
demanded Madame, who, having rallied from her (My) momentary paralysis, was now fierce and voluble as I had often seen her (My) before.

``You know, Madame, that you can rely on what I say, and I tell you that you were seen last night visiting this room, and with a key in your possession, opening this desk, and reading my letters and papers contained in it.
